column6: Using the life-centered nature of theatre as a medium of analysis, this course is designed to develop critically engaged audience members who are aware of the impact, significance and historical relevance of the interconnection between culture and theatre performance.
General introduction to acting: the actor's instrument, sensory awareness, personal and group response, objectives and tactics. Basic scene work.
An introduction to the art of lighting design, historical and technical perspectives. Emphasis on principles of design within a collaborative process. Two lecture hours plus two lab hours per week.

Principles, theories and basic skills of costume design and technology. Emphasis on aesthetics, the design process, fabric, construction techniques and craft materials. Two lecture hours plus two lab hours per week.
Principles, theories and basic skills of scenic design and technology. Emphasis on design elements, process of applied construction skills. Two lecture hours plus two lab hours per week.
Study of stage, TV and photographic makeup techniques and materials. Four lecture demonstration laboratory hours per week; special projects as assigned.
Offered irregularly when unusual recourses permit a topic different from existing courses. Topic will be announced when scheduled. Repeated registration permitted.
Principles, theories and techniques of play script analysis for theatrical production.

The evolution of the American musical from comic opera, European operetta and African American jazz to today's commercial Broadway stage. Students engage in the traditions, identity, and socio- economic development of the quintessential American art form: Musical Theatre.
Fundamentals of naturalistic acting and interaction; development of spontaneity, believability and a sense of truth; game playing and basic stage technique.
Performance-oriented class that will focus on techniques and styles of performance in musical theatre and cabaret from Gilbert and Sullivan to present. Repeatable for up to 12 hours.
Preparation and review of a portfolio of work, judged by the design technology faculty at the beginning of the spring semester. Student must pass to remain in the BFA design technology program.
Drafting techniques for all design/technology students. Includes plans elevations sections detailed drawings light plots.
Techniques of scene painting; emphasis on a variety of techniques through practical projects.
Beginning exploration of technical skills emphasizing the physical components of expressive action through integration of breath, text and body conditioning.
Breathing, physical alignment, sound and text explorations designed to develop relaxed, free and fully connected voice production for the actor. Proper use and care of the voice.

column2: ENTERTAINMENT ARTS AND TECHNOLOGY INTERNSHIP I
column6: Intensive professional experience in aspects of entertainment arts and technologies. Repeatable up to 10 hours.

column4: Freshmen or sophomores only and special approval.
column6: Practical experience in theatre production under faculty supervision. Available for lower-division students only. Required of all theatre majors. Repeatable.

column4: Freshmen or sophomores only and special approval.
column6: Practical experience in theatre performance under faculty supervision. Available for lower division students only. Required of all theatre majors. Repeatable.

column4: Freshmen or sophomores only and special approval.
column6: Practical experience in theatre management under faculty supervision. Repeatable for a total of 12 hours.

column2: HISTORY OF THEATRE AND DRAMA I
column4: THEA 21111, junior standing and special approval.
column6: Theatre history and drama in Europe from antiquity through the renaissance.

column2: HISTORY OF THEATRE AND DRAMA II
column6: Theatre history and drama in Europe and the United States from 1660 to 1900.

column2: HISTORY OF THEATRE AND DRAMA III
column6: Theatre history and drama in Europe and the United States from 1900 to the present.
The development of character in the realistic scene.
Further character and scene exploration; spontaneity and creative choice making.

column4: THEA 11303 and THEA 21111 and special approval.
column6: Theoretical and practical work in the process of play direction; the director's mission; play analysis and design collaboration; the rehearsal process.

column4: Junior standing and BFA design/technology student and special approval.
column6: Review of a portfolio of theatre and related work, and a review of the student's academic progress and coursework judged by the design/technology faculty at the beginning of the spring semester. Student must pass to remain in the BFA Design Technology program.
Exploration of the tools of the lighting designer applied to design choices; frequent paper design projects.
Theory and practice of costume design. Emphasis on play text analysis, formation of concepts, use of design elements and principles, period styles.
Basic patterning and construction techniques used in theatrical costuming; emphasis on flat and draped patterning.

column4: THEA 11622 and THEA 21521 and special approval.
column6: Basic history, theory and application of theatrical practice in scenery properties and electrics. Three lecture hours per week and lab arranged.
Theory and practice of scene design; emphasis on script analysis, formation of concepts, use of design elements and principles in period styles and genres.
Development of movement exploration and improvisation skills which focus on physical relationships in performance and utilize the components of energy, space and time.

column4: THEA 21301 and THEA 21800 and special approval.
column6: Continuation of Voice I. Explorations involve various texts and incorporation of voice principles at a more detailed level.
Theory and practice of group interpretation through the medium of Readers Theatre; selection, adaptation and performance techniques. Three lecture/laboratory hours per week.
Application of principles of playwriting to the longer play and to variations from traditional realism; play analysis and composition. Repeatable for a total of 6 hours.
(repeated registration permitted) offered irregularly when unusual resources permit a topic different from existing courses. Topic will be announced when scheduled.
(repeatable for a total of 6 hours) selected research topics in theatre; to be elected only after all coursework in study area completed.
A study of theatre and drama in the Native American, Hispanic-American, African-American and Asian-American communities in the United States from 1980 to the present.
Studies of how the gay and lesbian community has been represented in theatre. Frameworks will include the history of the community, political issues, identity questions and gender theory.

column2: THEATRE AND DRAMA IN AMERICA I
column6: History of theatre and drama in America from the beginning to c. 1900.

column2: THEATRE AND DRAMA IN AMERICA II
column6: The history of theatre and drama in America from c. 1900 to the present.
Comprehensively examines the history of American musical theater and incorporates the exploration of musical literature in production and performance.

Seminar in theatre history and literature providing an in-depth focus on selected topics such as: African-American theatre, women in theatre, politics and theatre, theatre in a multicultural society, costume history on stage/screen.

column2: ACTING FOUNDATIONS I/STANISLAVSKI AND MICHAEL CHEKHOV
column6: The Stanislavski and Michael Chekhov Techniques: A thorough exploration of Stanislavski‟s „Method of Physical Action,‟ and the internalization of Michael Chekhov‟s technique including „atmosphere,‟ „psychological gesture,‟ „qualities of movement.‟ Taught in the same semester as THEA 41304.
The application of the Stanislavski and Michael Chekhov Techniques to in-depth scene study using the plays of Odets, Miller, Williams, Shanley and others.

A study of the practical demands and requirements of a professional acting career with particular emphasis on audition skills. Also covered: pictures and resumes, making rounds, professional unions, casting directors, agents and managers, the job market and career prospects.

A study of the practical demands and requirements of a professional career in design and technology, including portfolio development, resumes, unions, job market, financial matters and career prospects. Use of computers as a resource and tool emphasized.

Advanced work in musical theatre performance techniques for junior- and senior-level students. Course content includes selecting appropriate musical theatre audition material and developing contrasting selections from the musical theatre repertory. Preparation for musical theatre auditions is included.

column4: THEA 11303 and THEA 31401 and special approval.
column6: Advanced work in directing for the theatre. Topics include the director as creative/interpretative artist and the director and the actor; students direct individual projects.

column4: Senior standing and BFA Design Technology student and special approval.
column6: Review of a portfolio of theatre and related work, and a review of the student's academic progress coursework and professional potential judged by the design technology faculty at the end of the fall semester. Student must pass to remain eligible for the BFA design technology degree.
Advanced study of the technologies used in lighting designs; instrument design, optics, dimmer and control systems, projection techniques and special effects.
Advanced study of lighting design, emphasizing artistic style and concept through a variety of design problems.
Sound design for the theatre, sound production and sound reinforcement techniques. Introduction to electronic equipment mixing consoles amplifiers speakers.

Advanced study in costume design. Genres styles in the context of performance spaces with an emphasis on research, practical considerations of costume production and communication between designer shop/personnel and designer director.
Examination of the processes related to the creation and procurement of scenic and costume props.
Studies in sound design, sound production and reinforcement for live performance. Advanced software applications will be explored.
Studies in the theories and practice of audio mixing in support of live vocal and musical performance. Topics include wired and wireless microphones and real time digital processing of audio.

column2: ADVANCED WIG AND MAKEUP TECHNIQUES-STAGE AND SCREEN
column6: Advanced study of the process of designing and executing wigs and makeup with an emphasis on standards in the profession. Some prosthetic work required.

column4: THEA 11522; and junior standing; and special approval.
column6: Studies in the application of automated lighting techniques to live performance emphasizing artistic style and concept through a range of programming problems.

column4: THEA 11622 and THEA 21521 and special approval.
column6: History of technical production practice, materials theory and application in scenic construction technology.

column2: HISTORY OF PERIOD STYLES FOR THEATRE DESIGNERS
column4: theatre (THEA) major with junior standing; and special approval.
column6: Students explore the way in which theatre designers approach period style in their own creative work.

column4: junior standing and THEA 11522 and THEA 11524 and THEA 11622 and THEA 21521.
column6: Advanced process techniques in rendering, model building and design presentation for the scenic costume and lighting designer in traditional and new media.
Advanced study in scenic design. Explores genres styles performance spaces including practical considerations.
Studies in the process and application of designing lighting for studio and event based television production.

column2: MOVEMENT FORM AND SPACE I-THE ACTOR'S PHYSICAL INSTRUMENT
column6: Development of technical skills emphasizing the physical components of expressive action through integration of breath, voice and body conditioning.
Principles and practices of managing theatrical-producing organizations. Problems of finance, personnel, policy, program building and public relations. Production participation as assigned.
Detailed investigation of the methodology used in stage managing a professional theatrical production including paperwork, rehearsals and calling a show.

column2: VOICE AND SPEECH I-THE ACTOR'S INSTRUMENT
column6: The use of exercise and specific text work to explore „centering‟ as it related to the vocal, physical and emotional process of the actor. Focus on extremes of emotional sounds and eliminating barriers and detrimental vocal habits/speech patterns.
The application of acting, movement, and voice and speech techniques to sonnets, monologues, soliloquies, and scenes from Shakespeare.

column2: ENTERTAINMENT ARTS AND TECHNOLOGY INTERNSHIP II
column6: Intensive advanced professional experience in aspects of entertainment arts and technologies. Repeatable up to 10 hours.
Intensive advanced training in practical aspects of production. Periodic seminars, laboratory sessions and performance in a theatre company. Repeatable for a total of 12 hours.

column6: Advanced practical experience in theatre production under faculty supervision. Available for upper division students only. Required of all theatre majors. Repeatable.

column4: Junior or senior standing and special approval.

Advanced practical experience in theatre management under faculty/staff supervision. Available for upper division students only. Repeatable for up to 12 hours.

column4: Special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Principles underlying playwriting for the contemporary theatre; analysis of short play form. May be repeated once.

column4: THEA 51026 and special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Application of principles of playwriting to the longer play and to variations from traditional realism; play analysis and composition. May be repeated once.

Advanced study in scenic design. Explores genres, styles, performance spaces, including practical considerations.

The application of acting, movement, and voice and speech techniques to sonnets, monologues, soliloquies, and scenes from Shakespeare.

column4: graduate standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: History of Dance from antiquity to 1900.

column6: History of the development of concert and theatrical dance forms from 1900.
Movement exploration with emphasis on the concepts of design structure and form.
The study of 20th-century costume and international dress.
Identification and analysis of textile fabric as the reflection of culture.

column4: Special approval of adviser and graduate standing.
column6: Students must register for course during the semester of their M.F.A. thesis project. Not repeatable.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing. 3.000 OR
column6: (Repeatable once) Intensive advanced training in practical aspects of production. Periodic seminars, laboratory sessions and performance in the Porthouse Theatre Company.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO GRADUATE STUDY IN THEATRE
column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Orientation to bibliography and research in the field of theatre with emphasis on application of research to performance.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Strategies for teaching, issues on implications of pedagogical practice and responsibilities of academic leadership.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Offered irregularly when unusual resources permit a topic different from existing courses. Topic will be announced when scheduled. Repeated registration permitted.
Independent study of an area or problem approved by divisional graduate coordinator in consultation with project director. Repeatable for maximum of 6 credit hours.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Research or individual investigation for master's-level graduate students. Credits may be applied toward meeting degree requirements if school approves.

column2: HISTORY OF THEORIES OF ACTING AND SPACE I
column4: pecial approval of instructor. Prerequisite: special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: History of theories of acting and space in the theatre from the beginning to ca. 1850.

column2: HISTORY OF THEORIES OF ACTING AND SPACE II
column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: History of theories of acting and space in the theatre.
An investigation of a period, historical/theoretical development, playwright/ practitioner/theorist (variable topics).
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
A survey of current software used in theatre production with an emphasis on applications for management, design and technical direction.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

column2: ACTING III SCENE STUDY-NATURALISM AND ABSURD
column4: Special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: In-depth scene study in the genres of Naturalism and Absurd theatre. Exploration of the works of Chekhov, Strindberg, Beckett and others.

column2: ACTING STYLES II: GREEK AND COMEDY OF MANNERS
column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Application of acting, movement, and speech techniques to these specific genres. Focus on style and physicalization using Greek and English Restoration playwrights as well as Molière, Wilde and others.

column2: MASTER OF FINE ARTS COMPREHENSIVE PROJECT IN ACTING
column4: THEA 61000; special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Intensive work in the development of the practical aspects of production; includes performance or exhibition of work, documentation of that work in a format appropriate for area and project, and an exit interview.

column2: MASTER OF FINE ARTS DESIGN AND TECHNOLOGY CULMINATING PROJECT
column4: THEA 61000; special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: An intensive experience in the development of design and/or technical aspects of a theatrical production; the scope of work may include but not necessarily be limited to research, drawings and drafting, renderings and associated digital image, video or audio files. Documentation, appropriate for the area and project, is presented at an exit interview.
Intensive analysis of dramaturgical theory. Scope of the inquiry dependent upon individual interests of those enrolled.

Collegial exploration of the intersections among creative and scholarly/critical/theoretical thinking. Students involved in the colloquium may be pursuing current creative projects under faculty supervision. Does not count toward degree.
Advanced drafting techniques for the technical director, scenic designer and lighting designer. Includes film, television, industrial and engineering graphic techniques.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Detailed exploration of the skills of designing lighting with emphasis on theatre, opera, ballet, alternative venues and professional standards.

column2: ADVANCED STUDIES IN COSTUME DESIGN FOR STAGE AND SCREEN
column6: Detailed exploration of skills in designing costumes for stage and screen. Emphasis on concept work, stylist work, accuracy in research, organizational skills and industry standards.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Advanced studies of techniques of millinery construction and 3D character construction with an emphasis on current practice in the industry.
Study of resource management for the professional shop. Topics business planning labor relations accounting budgeting and productivity techniques.
The theory and practice of structural and mechanical design for theatre production. Related issues in resource management for the professional shop.
Advanced study of the techniques used in painting scenery for theatre and television. Emphasizes professional standards and the practical application of skills.

column2: ADVANCED STUDY: SCENERY FOR STAGE AND SCREEN
column6: Detailed exploration of the skills of designing scenery with emphasis on theatre, opera, ballet, film, television and alternative venues and the professional standards associated with each area.

column2: MOVEMENT, FORM AND SPACE II-NEUTRAL AND CHARACTER MASK
column4: THEA 51701; special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Advanced skills and conditioning focusing on the physical and vocal qualities of characterization achieved through performance in masks.

column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: The study of diverse styles of choreography for the actor performing in Musical Theatre.

column2: VOICE AND SPEECH II-VOCAL DEMANDS AND DIALECTS
column4: pecial approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Voice principles are covered in depth and detail with emphasis on their applications to dialects, singing and media voice work.

column4: THEA 51801; special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: Training in methods and skills necessary for the singing actor. Focus on the integration and physicalization of lyrics and music.

column4: THEA 51801; special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: A comprehensive study of performance techniques and repertoire appropriate to the singing actor.

column6: Practical experience for the graduate student in theatre performance under faculty supervision.
Practical experience for the graduate student in theatre management under faculty/staff supervision. Repeatable for a total of 12 hours.

column6: (Repeatable for credit) Under faculty supervision, a student will serve as dramaturg to a school of Theatre and Dance production.
Practical experience for the graduate student in co-curricular theatre activities, under faculty supervision. Repeatable twice.

column4: Special approval of adviser and graduate standing.
column6: Intensive advanced training in practical aspects of production. Periodic seminars, laboratory sessions and performance in a theatre company or touring with Kent Theatre Ensemble. Repeatable for a maximum of 12 hours.

column4: graduate standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for a total of 6 credit hours) Development of advanced skills and abilities to mentor student performers in aspects of the profession, including professional behavior, understanding of the business and the actor‟s creative process. Major work done while participating in rehearsal and performance of main stage productions or assisting in THEA 451305 Professional Aspects. May be taken with THEA 62192 Practicum: Performance.

column4: graduate standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for a total of 6 credit hours) Development of advanced skills and abilities to mentor student performers in aspects of the profession, including professional behavior, understanding of the business and the actor‟s creative process. Major work done while participating in rehearsal of Porthouse productions. May be taken with THEA 62192 Practicum: Performance.

column4: THEA 61094; and graduate standing; and special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for a total of 6 credit hours) Application of strategies for teaching acting and other aspects of the art of theatre and performance at the college level. Development of advanced skills in course preparation, classroom management and pedagogical practice. Major work done teaching or assisting with undergraduate- and/or graduate-level studio acting classes.
Movement exploration with emphasis on the development of advanced choreographic techniques.
Practical experience for the graduate student in co-curricular theatre activities, under faculty supervision. Repeatable twice.
